Is there a particular set of requests that triggered this? The actual motivation seems a bit unclear. I haven't seen much activity in the technical-oversight-forum repo recently.

One of the Request from AMD is  https://github.com/openbmc/technical-oversight-forum/issues/24. 

I think this document helps both hw-vendors and OpenBMC maintainers to set guidelines for adding vendor specific features and speed-up merge process. 

Thanks @andrew for initiating this review request.
Yep, the AMD request is the main one right now and Patrick noted that he'd like something written down based on our TOF meeting before moving forward on this.
Hi Andrew, I've left a few requests and comments inline.
Perhaps put this paragraph before the two rhetorical questions above. From there you can tack on "This document aims to answer the following questions:"
Done
Ah.

Yes! More documents should have a "Philosophy" section.
Is this a goal to be achieved or a problem to be solved? The way the sentence is structured it feels hard to tell.
Hmm, neither. Just trying to make the point that we have friction between being agnostic and allowing some vendor-specific function in. Let me rephrase it a bit to see if I can clarify that.

If we're enumerating requirements I prefer we use a numbered list rather than a bullet list. That way we can succinctly refer to a specific requirement without reading out the requirement's description.
Done
"A device attached to the BMC ..." ? The grammar of "An attached device to the BMC" feels inside-out to me.
Done

Another Key area is vendor specific Kernel patches. Like handling BMC soc specific patches , which is available in SOC vendors public repository. As per coding guideline , kernel patches are not allowed , which is good. It will be good to set guidelines/criteria, to get patches in OpenBMC tree, without impacting OpenBMC code quality/support.
Let me reference the kernel-development.md file in here so people can understand the process.
No need for the apostrophe.
Done
I don't think this condition is necessary. "APIs which are not upstream" feels like it's enough.

Yeah, initially I had even more words here about how we'll take some openbmc/linux patches as long as it's being worked upstream but it got a bit long. Lets just trim it down to what you propose to keep it simple. I'll add a link to the kernel-development.md for people looking for more info.
I think we go with the statement that we don't import existing repositories at all.

Lets see if anyone else has a vote. I could see use cases where someone starts a repo off to the side, others find it and start using it, and at some point it's said "we should get this under OpenBMC". Ideally they start it within OpenBMC but there are times where that's not realistic due to schedule and such.
Done
I feel like this is a counter-statement and probably should go in the section above?

Hmm, well we have some repos like sdbusplus that are definitely getting used outside of OpenBMC. So I don't think we should preclude repos like that from being within OpenBMC. But, if a repo is only useful to OpenBMC, it should be in OpenBMC.
Done
I think that this section could also suggest sending the recipe to upstream openembedded.
Done
Lots of disjoint comments.

Is the design doc template the best model for this?  I see a lot of reading to be done before we get to what the rules are. I wonder if we should restructure this as something that extends or replaces:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/meta-layer-guidelines.md#meta-layer-recipes-should-only-point-to-well-maintained-open-source-projects


And maybe have sections that invert this:
```
Rules for openbmc repositories
<list of rules>

Rules for openbmc owned recipes
<list of rules>


Intent:

<paragraphs of why those two sections have those rules>

```


As currently organized, it takes a lot of reading to get to what 99% of folks are coming to a doc like this for, the rules.

I'm not seeing the bang for the buck on moving over to that. It seems like quite a bit of text as well but others can weigh in if they feel otherwise. The struggle with this doc is that for this first review of this doc, I wanted the "how we got to these requirements" to be the more important part of this review. Once we agree then you're right, the requirements will be the more important part. I'm fine if someone wants to come in after and refactor/move these requirements elsewhere.

I had a similar experience with https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/process/subproject-maintainership.md

Something to think about at least.
Bang for the buck on inverting the sections, or merging the meta-layer guidelines or both?  I think the former is more important, but I'm not super hung up on either.
I think for the purpose of _writing_ the document, the current order is necessary. However, for the purpose of _reading_ the document, it's better if it's inverted.
Yep, good way to put it AndrewJ. As the doc has now been written and reviewed, I'll invert things so the reqs come first.

I don't know if I necessarily agree with this.  The goal is having proper abstractions from the hardware such that we can implement something that works, have a reasonable chance that it survives more than 3 months, have a chance that it "just works" for the next implementer, and clients outside of OpenBMC implement against it as an API.


In terms of this doc, I would take this out, and put it more in the framework of maintainership.

"OpenBMC wants to enable as many machines as possible with as many common paths shared between machines as possible, under the hope of keeping stability in its implementation between systems."
Done

I think you've mixed up ideas here a little, and I'd like to see them separated in this doc.  There are two concepts:

- A Hardware specific feature (implementation for a driver, support for hardware, or other things that only exist on that platform).
- Support for a vendor-specific feature. (OEM extensions, debug APIs, Redfish, etc).

These are two different things that we accidentally combine quite often and quite easily.  Yocto differentiates between them with the "machine" and "distro" concepts.

I think as a matter of this policy, we need to be very clear about the difference, and the policies for each.  I suspect that hardware-specific-features, we could document a policy of "Don't break other people unnecessarily" and we'd be pretty close.

In terms of vendor-specific features, many of which apply to more than one system, we need to come up with a policy that doesn't tie those things to a specific platform, and abstracts them in a way similar to yocto.
Defined the 2 categories and broke into separate sections in requirements below.
nit, remove.  "latest clang features" I'm assuming is talking about clang-tidy, which is a manual process.
Done
I suspect this could be removed to the absentee maintainers documentation.  CI is great, I agree, but I'm not sure what it has to do with this policy.

Let me rephrase a bit, the point I was trying to make is that a repository hosted within OpenBMC is easier to maintain then a repository outside of OpenBMC. So philosophically I wanted to note that, but then talk about the drawbacks in the next paragraph of having so many repos.

i.e. new yocto update breaks a systemd service feature we've been utilizing, causing the need for multiple service file updates in multiple repositories. It was much easier to get that change into OpenBMC hosted repos vs. other external repos that OpenBMC CI machines were using.
ACK

Lets rephrase to something like
```
New repositories should be added in the case where they can be maintained over the long term without taking resources away from other project efforts.  Having a set of guidelines for this process helps to speed up new code development within the project.
```
Done

This is the thing I would like moved into its own category.  "I'm trying to implement my own API" is a different bar than than "I'm trying to support the existing interfaces on new hardware".  Mixing the two in this doc implies that they're the same.
Done

Lets invert this to something like "To add a repository to openbmc, it should meet the minimum bar X".

Hardware vendors, ODMs, and clients can publish what they want;  It's open source.  This document governs what we can do in openbmc/openbmc
Done

I'm not really sure what you intended here.  "exposing dbus interfaces" doesn't really seem like a reason we would avoid including something in the project.  By that argument, we shouldn't include systemd?  I suspect this needs some wording around the DBus interface namespacing, and that things outside of the project shouldn't be claiming the openbmc dbus interface naming conventions?

This came from our TOF discussion. The idea being that if it needs other OpenBMC repositories, it has incentive to be in OpenBMC. That's more for the software features though so I'll see if I can rephrase and move under that section.
ACK

Lets just remove this, and replace with a blanket statement about "writing hard rules for anything is hard without defeating intent, these are guidelines to be used by the openbmc TOF in their decision to approve or not approve new recipes or repos."
Done, added as blanket statement at start of requirements section.
I don't know if this is the case in all scenarios.  Arguably this would mean that libpeci and libpldm should exist outside of openbmc (yes, I recognize they're each different, and that's on purpose)?
Removed this section and focused on what is needed to get in.
In this case, we should arguably just not use the dependency at all, right?  Incompatible license doesn't seem like a care where we'd want an external repo that we pointed to.
Acknowledged
"have not been submitted to linux upstream"
Acknowledged

Lets rephrase this to "Does not have an existing and active maintainer".

Mentioning history implies that situations can never improve.
Done

Lets rephrase this a little:

It is a feature that is believed to be generally useful to the OpenBMC organization.
  - Determination made by the TOF.
Done
?  If it's consuming openbmc dbus apis, it's openbmc specific, and not hardware agnostic, right?

Not sure I get you on this one. This was from our TOF call where we tried to set some criteria on when it made sense to pull something into OpenBMC. If it consumes OpenBMC API's (like openpower-vpd-parser) then that could be an argument for it being under the OpenBMC org, even though it's supporting a vendor-specific VPD format. I tried to add a bit more clarity.

This part needs specified.  I don't think we should be adding any recipes to a meta-<vendor> repository, because (to pick on IBM a little) it mixes the idea of "machines that have an IBM power processor" with "Machines that implement IBMs software policies."

Not all IBM machines have a Power processor, and not all Power machines will take on IBMs software policies.

In a perfect world, I think we'd only implement hardware-specific details in a machine layer, and implement things that are specific to a vendor in a distro, but we're not really there yet.
Broke up requirements into the 2 sections and added the "perfect world" direction to philosophy section.
Found a typo, but it looks fine otherwise.
typo: strive
Done

It's not clear to me why I wouldn't always go this route (which isn't what we want, right)?  And ... we haven't added any requirements when going this route.

This should be our worst-case, but when we go this route we need to have some requirements / commitments from the external repository.  For example:

- we cannot have them re-writing git history once we add them.
- we need to have some kind of SLA commitment on fixing issues induced by newer compilers (especially if any machine in our CI system is leveraging these recipes).

> It's not clear to me why I wouldn't always go this route

Yeah, let me add some text to indicate the first preference is always to be under openbmc unless there is a valid reason not to.

> This should be our worst-case, but when we go this route we need to have some requirements / commitments from the external repository. For example:

I'll add

I think we said there is an additional requirement that repositories that depend on openbmc repositories _must_ be hosted by openbmc.  We don't want a spider web of dependencies.  If someone wants to change, for example, phosphor-dbus-interfaces we need to be able to apply the appropriate changes across all our repos and not have to go to other organizations in order to get CI passing.
Rewrote this section a bit to include this requirement.

Hopefully this is for vendors that are selling that hardware?  I want to make sure we have language that precludes us being expected to host code for some random CPLD design that Vendor X made that is only in Vendor X's own systems.

I'm struggling a bit with this one on where the line is. Like if you need the CPLD code to make the OpenBMC based system boot, why not? But then I get the point that that really could open a can of worms and a lot of that could be outside the scope of OpenBMC. So I made a general comment on it and we can always point back to the "Writing hard rules for anything..." at the start of the doc.

I'm worried about us getting to many "electrical engineer designed requirements" that we end up having to support long-term.

There are many BMC teams which are not working early enough in their system design, where someone makes a weird custom CPLD with a very specific protocol, and then the BMC team is like "I have to figure out how to support this".  I don't want that to become _our_ problem (in terms of long term maintenance) by accepting code for random pieces of one-vendor hardware.  If somebody is selling the device and has a published datasheet for it, fine, but not if it is "this one weird thing my system designers made me do".

> "this one weird thing my system designers made me do"

Yeah, one-off weird hardware designs should have equally one-off weird software hacks kept downstream. "More than one company uses this" seems like a reasonable bar for upstream.
